docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush paid tribute today to Lyndon B. Johnson as the father of Medicare, saying he wanted to build on Johnson's legacy by signing a bill to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare this year. ''My pen is ready,'' Mr. Bush said at a ceremony for the 38th anniversary of the Medicare law.

headline.main: Bush, at Medicare Birthday, Asks Again for Drug Benefits

docs.abstract: Pres Bush pays tribute to former Pres Lyndon B Johnson as father of Medicare, saying he wants to build on Johnson's legacy by signing bill to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare this year; Congressional negotiators are trying to work out differences between House and Senate versions of legislation; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The economy offered some signs of faster growth in the last six weeks, including early evidence of a pickup in manufacturing, the Federal Reserve said yesterday in a survey of regional economies. The report, known as the beige book, said that information from the 12 Federal Reserve districts ''provided additional signs that the pace of economic activity increased a notch during June and the first half of July.''

headline.main: A Fed Survey Sees More Hints Of a Revival

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve survey of regional economies finds some signs of faster growth in last six weeks, including early evidence of pickup in manufacturing; finds generally more positive assessments of current economic activity and increased optimism about economic outlook; map shows improvement by region (M)
docs.snippet: The economy offered some signs of faster growth in the last six weeks, including early evidence of a pickup in manufacturing, the Federal Reserve said yesterday in a survey of regional economies.    The report, known as the beige book, said that...

docs.lead_paragraph: Riding a wave of growing prosperity in health insurance, Aetna reported a 28 percent increase in profit in the second quarter, joining three other industry giants that have reported better-than-expected results in the last two weeks. Aetna reported net income of $138.4 million, or 87 cents a share, for the quarter, up from $108.2 million, or 70 cents a share, for the period a year earlier. Operating profits, calculated before investment results, taxes and special charges, rose to $203.9 million, or $1.28 a share, from $91.8 million, or 59 cents a share, a year ago, surpassing analysts' expectations of $1.02.

headline.main: Aetna Profits Are Up 28% As Health Insurers Prosper

docs.abstract: Aetna, health insurer, reports second-quarter net income rose 28 percent, to $138.4 million, up from $108.2 million in 2002 period; operating profits rose to $203.9 million from $91.8 million; chief executive Dr Jack W Rowe comments, interview (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Big Pickup Trucks Grow In Both Size and Popularity Sales of the largest pickups have been soaring for several years. But in coming months the competition for customers will accelerate as Japanese automakers rush into the market, now one of the most profitable. The trend toward bigger-than-ever pickups has broad implications for the safety of American drivers, the environment, oil consumption and the financial health of the auto industry. Big pickups are the most dangerous vehicles on the road for people riding in other vehicles -- much more dangerous even than large sport utility vehicles. [Page A1.]
docs.snippet: Big Pickup Trucks Grow In Both Size and Popularity  Sales of the largest pickups have been soaring for several years. But in coming months the competition for customers will accelerate as Japanese automakers rush into the market, now one of the most...

docs.lead_paragraph: Jason Lawson had a big pickup, but like a growing number of Americans he recently traded up to an even bigger one. ''It's an S.U.V. with an open back,'' Mr. Lawson, 33, said of his metallic gray Ford F-250 Crew Cab. The pickup weighs about three tons, empty, and has enough room in the cab for him, his wife, their two children in car seats and even the family's chocolate lab.

headline.main: Big and Fancy, More Pickups Displace Cars

docs.abstract: Sales of largest pickup trucks have been soaring for several years, and competition for customers is expected to grow sharply as Japanese automakers rush into market that has been dominated by America's Big Three; trend toward bigger-than-ever pickups has broad implications for safety of American drivers, environment, oil consumption and financial health of auto industry; big pickups, costing $40,000 and up, are most dangerous vehicle on road for people riding in other vehicles; average pickup uses more gasoline than average sport utility vehicle and therefore produces more gases that contribute to global warming; pickups, along with SUV's, are industry's most profitable vehicles and they get more profitable as they get larger and more luxurious; photo; graphs (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The California Assembly approved a nearly $100 billion state budget today that cuts deeply into education and health care spending but does not raise taxes. The 56-to-22 vote ended months of partisan debate arising from the state's record $38.2 billion deficit, which led, in large part, to the downgrading of the state's credit rating to near junk bond status and to the recall election facing Gov. Gray Davis on Oct. 7.

headline.main: California House Breaks Stalemate on Budget Plan

docs.abstract: California Assembly approves state budget of nearly $100 billion that cuts deeply into education and health care spending but does not raise taxes; photo; 56-22 vote ends months of partisan debate arising from $38.2-billion deficit; passage frees Gov Gray Davis to battle recall (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BY necessity, the family doctor has turned into a marketing manager of sorts, working as a go-between for patients and their health care and medicine providers. These days, a doctor's message to patients might be: take two aspirin, call me in the morning and, before you go, sign up with my advertising partners for information on their latest products.

headline.main: Rules on patient privacy force companies to seek new ways to distribute samples and information.

docs.abstract: Patient privacy provisions of federal health insurance law that took full effect this year are forcing pharmaceutical and health care companies to re-examine their partnerships with physicians and pharmacies and their approaches to direct marketing drives; doctors, health plans and health care providers can no longer disclose any personally identifiable data about patients, including their names and addresses, for marketing purposes; advertisers are turning to variety of opt-in programs as way to put their products and names in front of consumers; programs that give doctors samples and coupons along with mail-in personal data cards seem to be working (M)
docs.snippet: BY necessity, the family doctor has turned into a marketing manager of sorts, working as a go-between for patients and their health care and medicine providers.    These days, a doctor's message to patients might be: take two aspirin, call me in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: During a special live broadcast of the Vermont Public Radio program ''Switchboard'' before an audience of Iowa Democrats here, the host played two audio clips of his guest, Howard Dean. The first, from Dr. Dean's 1999 State of the State address, delivered when he was governor of Vermont, was a staid, nonpartisan call to view all Vermont as one community. In the second, which came from the official kickoff of Dr. Dean's presidential campaign last month, you could practically hear fists flying as he shouted over and over, ''You have the power!'' and ''We're going to take our country back!''

headline.main: Defying Labels Left or Right, Dean's '04 Run Is Making Gains

docs.abstract: Former Vermont Governor Howard Dean, who began with nonstop visits to Iowa and New Hampshire on threadbare budget, has burst out of obscurity to rank among top contenders in crowded field of Democratic presidential hopefuls; photos; stunning surge as top fund-raiser, using Internet, brought in $7.6 million in second quarter of year, mostly in small contributions from 59,000 people; 54-year-old physician, with his intense opposition to Iraq war, call for universal health insurance and civil union legislation, is seen as most liberal candidate, but his success in Vermont lay in keeping liberals in check; Dean, in 11 years, restrained spending to turn large deficit into surplus, cut taxes, forced many on welfare to work, abandoned sweeping health care reform for incremental measures, antagonized environmentalists, won top NRA rating and embraced business interests; at home he is considered not idealistic maverick but shrewd politician with ambitious eye on next step; record as governor detailed (L)

docs.section_name: Technology; Front Page; Health; U.S.; Washington

docs.lead_paragraph: Three Paralympic athletes filed a federal discrimination lawsuit against the United States Olympic Committee yesterday, claiming the organization gave better benefits to Olympic athletes and violated disabilities law. The wheelchair athletes Scot Hollonbeck of Atlanta, Tony Inguez of Aurora, Ill., and Jacob Heiveil of Bothell, Wash., said the U.S.O.C. should be giving Paralympians the same health insurance, grants, living-expense stipends and opportunities as Olympians.
docs.abstract: Paralympic athletes Scot Hollonbeck, Tony Inguez and Jacob Heiveil file federal discrimination lawsuit, alleging that United States Olympic Committee gives better benefits to Olympic athletes (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Edwards, a Democratic presidential contender, wants to require parents to have health insurance for their children, making medical care an American birthright much like education. Mr. Edwards, of North Carolina, wants $25 billion annually in tax credits to help parents pay the cost of enrolling their children in private or government plans.

headline.main: Candidate Proposes Requiring Health Insurance for Children

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential contender Sen John Edwards says nation's 12 million uninsured children should be first priority in overhauling health care system; proposes annual $25 billion in tax credits to help parents pay cost of obtaining health insurance for their children; photo (M)
